  • Seed Investors Are Shifting to Quicker Exits: Here‚Äôs Why üí∏

    Venture returns are down, and seed investors are adjusting accordingly. To meet limited partner demands for faster liquidity, they‚Äôre opting for earlier exits. This shift is shaking up how smaller funds manage their early-stage investments. [TechCrunch]

  • AI's Impact on SaaS Growth: The Shift From Process to Intelligence ü§ñ

    Jacco van der Kooij lays it out: AI is replacing traditional, process-driven SaaS growth strategies with intelligent, self-compounding systems. The result? Greater efficiency and scalability that‚Äôs changing the game.

  • Not All Unicorns Stay $1B: A Stanford Study Unpacks the Risks ü¶Ñ

    Stanford‚Äôs latest research exposes the risk in chasing unicorns: many $1B+ startups lose their valuation due to overvaluation. Andreessen Horowitz may be excellent at spotting them, but it‚Äôs clear that being early doesn‚Äôt guarantee success. [Doug Dyer]

  • VCs Are Rethinking Deal Sourcing: Here‚Äôs the New Approach üîç

    Sharon Vosmek shares the scoop on Astia Fund‚Äôs ‚Äòsift‚Äô strategy - an innovative deal sourcing method designed to lower failure rates by making smarter startup selections. It‚Äôs a new era in VC with more precision in backing. [Venture Capital Journal]

  • Space-Tech Funding Set for Record-Breaking Year üöÄ

    2025 is shaping up to be a blockbuster year for space-tech investments. Late-stage deals are pouring into established players, especially in defense and space exploration technologies. [PitchBook]

  • The Dark Side of the 9-9-6 Work Culture in Startups ‚è∞

    The grueling 996 work culture - 12-hour days, 6 days a week - might be a startup‚Äôs shortcut to growth. But the price? Burnout and mental health breakdowns that threaten long-term sustainability. [PitchBook]

  • Why Data Is the New Code in the AI Era üíæ

    In AI-driven SaaS, data has eclipsed code as the true kingmaker. The right data architecture is what drives workflow efficiency and competitive advantage - making data a core differentiator in the industry‚Äôs evolution. [Tomasz Tunguz]
